metadata.title: High power nano-Nb2O5 negative electrodes for lithium-ion batteries

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: High power nano-Nb2O5 negative electrodes for lithium-ion batteries Author: Mechthild Lübke Afriyanti Sumboja Ian Johnson Dan J.L. Brett Paul R. Shearing Zhaolin Liu Jawwad A. Darr PII: S0013-4686(16)30261-4 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.electacta.2016.01.226 Reference: EA 26608 To appear in: Electrochimica Acta Received date: 21-11-2015 Revised date: 27-1-2016 Accepted date: 31-1-2016 Please cite this article as: Mechthild Lübke, Afriyanti Sumboja, Ian Johnson, Dan J.L.Brett, Paul R.Shearing, Zhaolin Liu, Jawwad A.Darr, High power nano-Nb2O5 negative electrodes for lithium-ion batteries, Electrochimica Acta http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2016.01.226 This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
High power nano-Nb2O5 negative electrodes for lithium-ion batteries Mechthild Lübke,1,2 Afriyanti Sumboja,2 Ian Johnson,1 Dan J.L. Brett,3 Paul R. Shearing,3 Zhaolin Liu2 and Jawwad A. Darr1* 1 Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WC1H 0AJ, U.K. 2 Institute of Materials Research and Engineering (IMRE), A*STAR (Agency for Science, Technology and Research), 2 Fusionopolis Way, Innovis #08-03, Singapore 138634, Republic of Singapore. 3 Electrochemical Innovation Lab, Department of Chemical Engineering, University College London, Torrington Place, London, WC1E 7JE, U.K. *Corresponding author: Professor Jawwad A. Darr Christopher Ingold Laboratories Department of Chemistry University College London 20 Gordon Street London, WC1H 0AJ j.a.darr@ucl.ac.uk Office telephone: +44 (0)20 7679 4345 Fax: +44 (0)20 7679 7463 Mobile: +44 (0)7941 928875 Research webpages http://www.ucl.me.uk
Highlights
 High surface area semi-crystalline Nb2O5 can be directly synthesized via CHFS.  The as-obtained Nb2O5 displayed excellent electrochemical performance.  At high current rates, the Nb2O5 behaved like an oxide supercapacitor material.  Pseudocapacitive reactions contributed to >63% of the total charge at 5 mV s-1.
Graphical abstract
Abstract Nano-sized, semi-crystalline niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) was synthesized in a single step via a continuous hydrothermal process. The nanomaterial was characterized using a range of analytical techniques including powder X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. The “as-prepared” Nb2O5 nanomaterial was investigated as negative electrode for a lithium-ion battery and was shown to be stable during electrochemical cycling (98.6 %
capacity retention after 800 cycles) and showed promising high rate performance, with a specific capacity of 43 mAh g-1 at an applied current of 10,000 mA g-1 (in the wide potential range of 0.05 to 3 V vs Li/Li+). Scan rate tests were used to investigate the proportion of stored charge from diffusion-limited processes and that from surface effects, which showed that at the higher currents, charge storage from the latter was dominant.
Keywords: continuous hydrothermal synthesis; anode; niobium; high power; pseudocapacitance
1. Introduction
In times of increasing energy demand, increased concerns over global warming and the movement towards more renewable energy sources, new efficient energy storage devices are needed. In this regard, lithium-ion batteries are a promising choice, not only because of their high specific energy, but also because of their ability to deliver high power output [1]. In general, a lithium-ion battery consists of a negative and a positive electrode, which are separated through an ion-conductive separator soaked with an organic electrolyte containing lithium-ions. Lithium-ions can move between the electrodes in order to be reversibly inserted / extracted. For low surface area and well defined electrodes made from suitable materials, this process happens at defined potentials vs Li/Li+; however, for nano-sized versions of the same materials, these potentials can vary considerably [2]. In Figure 1, the charge storage profile for potentiodynamic and galvanostatic electrochemical testing is presented. For bulk electrode materials, the diffusion-limited insertion process (battery-like) is potential dependent for each material, whereas for nano-sized, high surface area electrode materials the charge is also stored by surface effects (oxide supercapacitor-like), which result in less potential dependent charge storage [3]. The surface effects can be defined as a mixture of physical double-layers and pseudocapacitive fast Faradaic surface reactions [4]. For the pseudocapacitive process, the amount of charge (ΔQ) from Faradaic charge transfer processes, depends on the change in applied potential (ΔE). The derivative d(ΔQ)/d(ΔE) is equivalent to capacitance, and therefore the amount of stored charge is “linearly” proportional to the applied potential [5]. As batteries show relatively high energy density, and oxide supercapacitors tend to show high power performance, nano-sizing known lithium-ion battery electrode materials may be one solution for high power and high energy lithium-ion batteries.
Recently, amorphous insertion / intercalation electrode materials have been increasingly considered as possible high energy and high power electrode materials for lithium-ion and sodium-ion batteries [6], either for the negative [7-9] or the positive electrode [10, 11]. Interestingly, for the negative electrode side, it was possible to use materials such as V2O5 [7, 9] and Li4Ti5O12 [8] in the potential range of 0 to 3 V vs Li/Li+. For each of these reports, the enhanced electrochemical performance was explained to be due to higher ionic diffusion (larger access of lithium-ions from the electrolyte into the host and opening of diffusion pathways) in the amorphous phase compared to the crystalline counterpart. Moreover, Oh et al. described that a wider operational potential window was probably due to a wider variety of electrochemically non-equivalent lithium-ion storage sites; vacant lattice sites can provide both cation and anion vacancies, whilst void spaces, cluster gaps or interstitial sites can also be present in this regard [9]. For similar materials (surface areas of 80 m2 g-1 [7] and 15 m2 g-1 [9] for a V2O5 aerogel), the shape of potentiodynamic and galvanostatic data plots can be described as a mixture of battery-like and oxide supercapacitor-like behaviour [7-9]. This might support the idea that even for less crystalline, amorphous or nano-sized electrode materials, a significant portion of the charge storage can be governed by surface effects, e.g. pseudocapacitive processes.
Niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) is an ideal high power electrode material in lithium-ion batteries, as it is relatively inexpensive, environmentally benign and stable in a wide range of temperature and pH conditions [12-14]. By comparison to Nb2O5 in lithium-ion batteries, graphite electrodes can suffer from low power density [15, 16]. The specific capacity of crystalline Nb2O5 (200 mAh g-1) is relatively modest compared to other materials like lithium metal, Si, Sn, graphite (3860, 4200, 993, 372 mAh g-1, respectively), but Nb2O5 shows the potential to deliver high power densities due to its high rate performance (combination of
lithium-ion intercalation and fast charge storage arising from surface effects), including charge / discharge times of only a few seconds [12-14, 17]. Density functional theory (DFT) analysis by Ganesh et al showed that high-rate intercalation pseudocapacitative behavior in this material is due to local charge-transfer at all adsorption sites (leading to high energy), open channels that reduce the diffusion barrier for lithium-ions to hop between these (leading to high power) and the lack of first-order phase transformation upon lithiation / delithiation (leading to higher capacitive charge storage) [18].
Several groups have reported the electrochemical performance of Nb2O5 in lithium-ion batteries [13, 14, 17, 19-26], and shown promising high power performances in the potential range 1.2 (or 1.0) to 3.0 V vs Li/Li+. Pioneering work by Dunn et al., suggested that high rate charge storage in these and similar materials was mainly due to a mixture of intercalation and pseudocapacitive processes and that charge storage in Nb2O5 was greatest for the orthorhombic phase [12, 14]. Sasidharan et al. investigated pseudohexagonal hollow nanospheres (BET surface area of 96 m2 g-1) as a negative electrode material and achieved a capacity of 172 mAh g-1 after 250 cycles at a rate of 200 mA g-1 [27]. Kong et al. prepared mesoporous orthorhombic Nb2O5 (BET surface area of 43 m2 g-1) films capable of charge storage via lithium-ion intercalation and pseudocapacitive processes; an initial capacity of ca. 178 mAh g-1 (quoted as 640 C g-1) was obtained at a current density of 625 mA g-1 and this cell could maintain a stable capacity of ca. 156 mAh g-1 (quoted as 560 C g-1) after 300 cycles (mainly charge storage via intercalation). In the same report, the material showed excellent high-rate capability of ca. 125 mAh g-1 (quoted as 450 C g-1) at 12,500 mA g-1, which was largely due to oxide supercapacitor-like pseudocapacitive charge storage [28]. Wei et al. reported the use of orthorhombic Nb2O5 “nanobelt” as negative lithium-ion electrodes, which reached a specific capacity of 250 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 and 50 mAh g-1 at 10,000 mA g-1, respectively [17]. In contrast, Liu et al. reported orthorhombic Nb2O5
“nanosheets”, which showed a high specific capacity of 184 mAh g-1 at 200 mA g-1 and high rate capability of 90 mAh g-1 at 1,000 mA g-1 [29]. Wang et al. investigated carbon-coated orthorhombic Nb2O5 “nanowires” (BET surface area of 98 m2 g-1), which revealed a capacity of 186.8 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 and 140 mAh g-1 at 5,000 mA g-1 [26]. Surprisingly, to the authors’ knowledge, this material is rarely reported in a wider potential window (i.e. down to near 0 V vs Li/Li+).
Herein, semi-crystalline Nb2O5 was synthesized using a direct and continuous hydrothermal flow synthesis (CHFS) process [30-32]. The CHFS process as developed by the authors [33], generates nanoparticle slurries in water by mixing a flow of supercritical water (TC = 374 °C, Pc = 22.1 MPa) with a flow of aqueous metal salts (T= 20 °C, Pc = 22.1 MPa), which results in rapid / simultaneous hydrolysis and dehydration of the metal salt to form small particles of the respective oxide(s) [34]. The short reaction time, of fractions of a second, reduces particle size and some Ostwald-ripening and generally results in particles with a narrow size distribution. The as-prepared Nb2O5 nanomaterial was investigated as a negative electrode in a lithium-ion battery, without any further heat-treatment or chemical modification of the material. The printed electrode from this material was investigated electrochemically in the wide potential range of 0.05 to 3.00 V vs. Li/Li+. This potential range is significantly wider than the range of ca. 1 to 3 V vs. Li/Li+ that has been used for electrochemical cycling of similar materials in lithium-ion batteries in the literature [13, 14, 17, 19-26]. In order to understand the behaviors of the Nb2O5 nanomaterial, the charge storage mechanisms of the material was investigated via scan rate tests (battery-like or oxide supercapacitor-like).

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis
sections.text: The nanoparticles were synthesized using a laboratory scale CHFS reactor incorporating a patented confined jet mixer (CJM) [35]. The basic design can be found in the literature [31, 34]. The CJM is essentially a highly efficient co-current mixing device made from SwagelokTM fittings that allows the ambient temperature metal salt solutions to mix with the supercritical water feed to form nanoparticles “in flow” and without blockages. The laboratory scale CHFS process is similar to the pilot scale CHFS process described elsewhere [30, 32, 36] but on ca. 1/5 of the scale. In the lab-scale CHFS process used herein, three identical diaphragm pumps (Primeroyal K, Milton Roy, Pont-Saint-Pierre, France) were used to supply three pressurized (24.1 MPa) feeds. Pump 1 supplied a feed of DI water at a flow rate of 80 mL min-1, which was then heated to 450 °C in flow using a 7 kW electrical water heater. Pump 2 supplied 0.1 M ammonium niobate (V) oxalate hydrate (Sigma-Aldrich, >99.99%, Steinheim, Germany) at a flow rate of 40 mL min-1 and pump 3 supplied DI water at a flow rate of 40 mL min-1. The feeds from pumps 2 and 3 were combined at room temperature in a dead volume tee-piece. This precursor mixture was then brought into contact with the flow of supercritical water (co-currently) in the CJM resulting in a reaction temperature of ca. 335 °C (residence time ca. 5 s). At the end of the CHFS process, the particle-laden flow was cooled to ca. 40°C using a pipe-in-pipe counter-current heat exchanger (cooler), before passing through a back-pressure regulator (BPR) and being collected. The resulting nanoparticle-laden slurry was cleaned by allowing the solids to settle by gravity before washing with DI water (10 MΩ) and then freeze-dried (Virtis Genesis 35XL) by cooling to -60 °C followed by slow heating under vacuum of <100 mTorr over a period of 24 h. The dried powders were used directly for electrode preparation with no further processing.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization
sections.text: Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were obtained on a STOE diffractometer using Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71 Å) over the 2θ range 3 to 30° with a step size of 0.5° and step time of 20 s. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were collected using a Thermo Scientific K-alpha™ spectrometer using Al-Kα radiation and a 128- channel position sensitive detector. Survey scans were conducted at energy of 150 eV and high resolution region scans were conducted at 50 eV. The XPS spectra were processed using CasaXPS™ software (version 2.3.16). The binding energy scale was calibrated by a C 1s peak at 284.5 eV. The size and morphology of the crystallites were determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using a Jeol JEM 2100 – LaB6 filament. The system was equipped with a Gatan Orius digital camera for digital image capturing. Samples were prepared by briefly ultrasonically dispersing the powder in ethanol (>99.5%, EMPLURA, Darmstadt, Germany) and pipetting drops of the dispersed sample on to a 300 mesh copper film grid (Agar Scientific, Stansted, UK). Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area measurements were carried out using N2 in a micrometrics ASAP 2020 Automatic High Resolution Micropore Physisorption Analyzer. The samples were degassed at 150 ○C (12 h) under vacuum before measurements.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrode preparation and electrochemical characterization
sections.text:
The nano-sized samples were used as the electrode active material without any further posttreatment. The slurry for the electrode was prepared with a content of 70 wt% active material, 20 wt% conductive agent (carbon black, Super P, Alfa Aesar, Heysham, UK) and 10 wt% polyvinylidene fluoride, (PVDF, PI-KEM, Staffordshire, UK). PVDF was dissolved in NMP (N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, Sigma Aldrich, St. Louis, USA) for at least 1 hour at room
temperature before adding the active material and conductive agent. The mixtures were milled and the slurry was cast on a copper foil (PI-KEM, Staffordshire, UK) and dried in an oven at 70 °C for 1 hour and then left overnight at room temperature. Electrodes with a diameter of 16 mm were punched out, pressed and finally dried overnight at 70 °C. The electrodes had an active material mass loading of 1.1 ±1 mg cm-2. Electrochemical experiments were performed using a two-electrode CR2032-type coin cell, which was assembled in an argon-filled glovebox with O2 and H2O limited below 50 ppm. The counter electrode was lithium metal foil (PI-KEM, Staffordshire, UK). The separator (glass microfiber filters, Whatman, Buckinghamshire, UK) was saturated with an organic electrolyte of LiPF6 in 3:7 wt% ethylene carbonate/ethyl methyl carbonate (BASF, Ludwigshafen, Germany) for all measurements except the cyclic voltammetry (CV), where the organic electrolyte was 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC/DEC (1:1:1, v/v). Several measurements were performed using an Arbin Instrument Model BT-2000 battery tester (Caltest Instruments Ltd, Guildford, UK) at room temperature. The specific current rate test was performed between an applied current of 100 to 10,000 mA g-1 in the potential range 0.05 to 3 V vs Li/Li+. The electrochemical performance was investigated by CV in the potential range of 0.05 to 3 V vs Li/Li+ with scan rates ranging from 0.5 to 5 mV s-1 using a galvanostat/potentiostat (PGSTAT302, AUTOLAB, Metrohm). The specific current and specific capacity was calculated based on the mass of active material in each printed electrode.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
A light yellow nanoparticle slurry of Nb2O5 was obtained from the CHFS process, and after freeze drying, a free flowing powder in a yield of >90% was obtained. The as-prepared nanomaterial was used for investigations in lithium-ion batteries without any further
treatment. Powder XRD data revealed large broad ill-defined peaks (Figure 2a). The powder XRD data was compared to various Nb2O5 ICSD database patterns, and the monoclinic form with space group C 1 2/m 1(12) was found to be the closest reasonable match (similar to ICSD 25765); other than this, there were no other phases detected, such as NbO2. Moreover, the powder XRD data suggested that the samples were possibly semi-crystalline and most likely had a small particle size. XPS was used to determine the valence state of the metal ion in the niobium oxide (Figure 2b). The Nb-3d level binding energies were 210.72 eV (Nb 3d5/2) and 207.96 eV (Nb 3d3/2) with a spin orbit splitting of 2.76 eV, assigned to the core levels of Nb5+, which suggested the niobium was in the 5+ oxidation state. TEM images of the sample, revealed very small particles of ca. 7 nm in size that appeared to be poorly crystalline (see Figures 2c and 2d). There were only a few interlayers detectable for which the observed d-spacing was 0.39 nm (Figure 2e). The BET surface area (nitrogen) was conducted on the as-prepared powder and gave a value of 158 m2 g-1.
The lithium-ion insertion and extraction process for crystalline Nb2O5 can be described by Equation 1, where 𝑥 ≤ 2 (corresponding to 200 mAh g-1).
𝑥Li+ + 𝑥e- + Nb2O5 ↔ Li𝑥Nb2O5 (1)
Figure 3 shows the cyclic voltammetry for the as-prepared Nb2O5. The irreversible capacity loss during the first cycle was always around 300 mAh g-1 for these measurements. The high surface area of 158 m2 g-1 for the Nb2O5 was expected to increase the quantity of side reactions of the electrolyte for the initial solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation. An irreversible peak was observed at ca. 0.6 V vs Li/Li+, which was due to reaction of electrolyte
with the carbon additive in the electrode (SEI formation) [37, 38]. Interestingly, the authors observed that the electrochemical activity of the active material was extended beyond the typical range for the redox couple of Nb5+ ↔ Nb3+ and the CV profile did not show clear insertion peaks at well-defined potentials vs Li/Li+, suggesting the charge storage process occurred via both lithium-ion insertion and surface effects (Figure 1), which was consistent with the observation of a poorly crystalline or amorphous negative electrode material [7-9].
Further investigations using potentiodynamic methods were explored in order to understand the nature of the charge storage (Figure 4a). The current in a scan rate experiment can be expressed by a power law (Equation 2), where 𝑖 is the current (A), 𝑎 and 𝑏 are arbitrary coefficients and 𝜈 is the potential scan rate (V s-1) [39, 40].
𝑖 = 𝑎𝜈𝑏 (2)
The coefficient 𝑏 varies between 0.5 to 1, with a value of 0.5 being characteristic of a diffusion-limited process (charge storage via lithium-ion insertion, battery-like) and a value of 1 for a capacitive process (charge storage via surface capacitive effects, oxide supercapacitor-like). For further quantification, the different charge storage mechanisms were separated, as described previously [3, 12, 14, 39-42]. At a fixed potential, the current response can be seen as a combination of the two mentioned charge storage mechanisms. The surface capacitive effect shows fast kinetics and can be expressed as 𝑘1𝜈 (𝑏 = 1), whereas the diffusion-controlled (lithium-insertion) process can be expressed as 𝑘2𝜈 1 2 (𝑏 = 0.5) (Equation 3).
𝑖𝐸 = 𝑘1𝜈 + 𝑘2𝜈 1 2 (3)
𝑖𝐸/𝜈 1 2 = 𝑘1𝜈 1 2 + 𝑘2 (4)
The current was measured for each scan rate at a certain potential. A plot of 𝑖𝐸/𝜈 1 2 versus 𝜈 1 2 was used to calculate 𝑘2 from the y-intercept and 𝑘1 from the gradient of Equation 4 (Figure 4b). The obtained 𝑘1 value was then used to quantify the amount of charge stored via surface effects at each potential. As seen in Figure 4b, the slope and y-intercept of the linear fitted line showed a trend for the potential dependence. In the potential range of expected lithium-ion insertion, 𝑘1 was lower compared to the area where the electrochemical activity was not expected. The calculated current that resulted from surface effects was determined for each scan rate, which was then plotted against the overall measured current (see grey area in Figure 4c) and used to finally calculate the contribution of stored charge arising from surface effects. As shown in Figure 4d, the charge storage arising from surface effects increased drastically with increasing scan rate; from 29 % at 0.5 mV s-1 (180 mAh g-1, 100 min per charge/discharge) to 63 % at 5 mV s-1 (98 mAh g-1, 10 min per charge/discharge). Thus, calculation of the area as described above, provides a qualitative indication of the relative contributions from charge stored via surface effects (pseudocapacitance and Helmholtz double-layer charge) and diffusion-limited processes (classical lithium-ion insertion). The simultaneous charge storage via diffusion-limited and surface effects at the full width of electrochemical potential window of the electrode material was also observed before for amorphous MoO3 (200 m2 g-1) [43], spinel Fe3O4 [44] and V2O5-anchored carbon nanotubes [45]. Clearly, with shorter charge/discharge times, the storage mechanism for high surface area semi-crystalline Nb2O5 became more dependent on the surface effects (due to diffusion limitations), similar to that seen in nanocrystalline oxide supercapacitor materials [14, 42]. Overall, we can conclude that one reason for the expanded electrochemical activity in a wide potential window was found in the oxide supercapacitor-like behavior.
The C-rate relates to the full theoretical charge / discharge within one hour for 1 C, but this relates to the bulk delithiation / lithiation charge storage mechanism (battery-like). However,
the material presented herein showed significant charge storage via surface effects; thus, the authors will hereafter use the term “theoretical C-rate” (1 C corresponds to 200 mA g-1) and the real measured charge / discharge time for each applied current rate.
At very low applied currents rates of 50 mA g-1 (equivalent to 0.25 C, ca. 4 hours charge or discharge, see Figure 5a), the Coulombic efficiency was low at about 80 %, whereas at a higher applied current of 500 mA g-1 (2.5 C, discharge time ca. 20 minutes, see Figure 5b), the Coulombic efficiency was always > 99.8 % after the initial cycles. The high Coulombic efficiency resulted in a very high cycle life of more than 800 cycles with 98.6 % capacity retention (initial 145 mAh g-1 and last cycle 143 mAh g-1). The reason for the poor Coulombic efficiency at low current rates can be explained by reviewing the potential vs specific capacity plot data (see Figure 5c). In this plot, the additional charge storage during lithiation was mainly at low potentials vs Li/Li+. This could be due to electrolyte destruction at the metal oxide surface because no stable solid electrolyte-interface was formed [46]. However, very stable and high Coulombic efficiencies above 99.5% were observed for applied currents > 100 mA g-1. The stable electrochemical cycling performance suggested an absence of significant electrolyte destruction, as most of the fast charge storage process (at high currents), were due to rapid surface chemical process. Moreover, the specific capacities at higher current rates were excellent, e.g. 120 mAh g-1 at 1000 mA g-1 (equivalent of 5 C, 7 min charge or discharge), 74 mAh g-1 at 5000 mA g-1 (equivalent of 25 C, 50 s charge or discharge) and 43 mAh g-1 at 10,000 mA g-1 (equivalent of 50 C, 14 s charge or discharge), see Figure 5d. Several works could show beneficial rate performance for nanosized electrode materials because of the reduced lithium-ion diffusion path lengths [47, 48]. As the diffusion is a time-dependent process, nanosized materials can be expected to show far less time for the full lithiation of a single particle. The poorly crystalline 7 nm particles showed excellent rate performances, which might be also a result of decreased lithiation path lengths. Recently,
some groups investigated niobium oxides in an expanded potential window. Chen et al. investigated microsized, urchin-shaped Nb2O5 (0.05 to 3 V vs Li/Li+) and could see a reversible capacity of 390 mAh g-1 after 200 cycles [49]. Most stored charge of 75% was measured between 1 to 3 V vs Li/Li+ at 50 mA g-1, whereas the used material herein showed ca. 17% charge storage in the same range at 50 and 500 mA g-1. The difference might be due to higher crystallinity and lower surface area of the microsized, urchin-shaped Nb2O5 which both increase the diffusion-limited battery-like behavior. Ma et al. investigated orthorhombic nano-sheet Nb2O5 (0.01 to 3 V vs Li/Li+) and could measure a reversible capacity of 225 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles at 100 mA g-1 and 105 mAh g-1 at the highest applied current of 1,000 mA g-1 [50]. The material did not show typical lithiation / delithiation plateaus during cycling and showed also only 9% charge storage (compared to the overall charge) between 1 to 3 V vs Li/Li+ at 100 mA g-1. Unfortunately, no explanation for the expanded potential window was given in either work. Clearly, the particle characteristics (size, morphology) seem to play a crucial role for the electrochemical behavior.
The obtained high power characteristics herein were remarkable for such a wide operational potential window vs Li/Li+ (negative electrode material). Notably, the potential range used herein is significantly wider than the vast majority of analogous literature on similar materials. As the Coulombic efficiency was very high at higher current rates, such a material might be useful as a negative electrode material in a high power hybrid supercapacitor with an activated carbon positive counter-electrode in the future (electrochemical double-layer capacitor electrode) [51, 52]. As such, it would be expected that by increasing the operational potential window the energy and power density of the device increases.
In closing, the use of amorphous phases in alkali-ion batteries shows promising high power performances with high stability. The charge storage mechanism is still not fully understood, but there are significant observations to suggest that one major property might be the surface
area and the resulting charge storage via surface effects contributing to excellent high rate capacities and expanded electrochemical activity of the electrode material in a wider potential window.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: High surface area, semicrystalline Nb2O5 nanoparticles were synthesized in a single step via a continuous hydrothermal process. The high surface area and defective structure of the nanomaterial was believed to be responsible for the high charge storage capacity arising from surface effects which might also be a reason for the expanded electrochemical activity. Although the material was cycled in a wider potential window than that normally used in the literature, the cycle stability was still excellent (98.6% capacity retention after 800 cycles). Furthermore, high rate capacities were obtained, including 43 mAh g-1 at a very high applied current of 10,000 mA g-1. This showed promising electrochemical performances for high power applications as the material performance shifts from battery-like to oxide supercapacitor-like behavior with higher rates. These initial promising results offer new routes for the future development of high power negative electrodes. Given the authors have developed pilot scale CHFS process facilities at UCL, they envisage that there will be opportunities to scale-up as well as control the crystallinity and particle size in the future, to gain a more comprehensive understanding of particle properties vs. electrochemical behaviors (e.g. capacity and width of operational potential window). The results of these endeavors will be reported in due course.

metadata.abstractText: Nano-sized, semi-crystalline niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) was synthesized in a single step via a continuous hydrothermal process. The nanomaterial was characterized using a range of analytical techniques including powder X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. The “as-prepared” Nb2O5 nanomaterial was investigated as negative electrode for a lithium-ion battery and was shown to be stable during electrochemical cycling (98.6 % capacity retention after 800 cycles) and showed promising high rate performance, with a specific capacity of 43 mAh g at an applied current of 10,000 mA g (in the wide potential range of 0.05 to 3 V vs Li/Li). Scan rate tests were used to investigate the proportion of stored charge from diffusion-limited processes and that from surface effects, which showed that at the higher currents, charge storage from the latter was dominant.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
